Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County Superior Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 1 because the acts and omissions giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Hampden County.

Seigel v. Berkshire Life Ins. Co., 273 M.raw_text: Seigel v. Berkshire Life Ins. Co., 273 Mass. 423 (1930)
Seigel v. Berkshire Life Ins. Co., 273 M.proposition: At all relevant times, the Defendant owed the Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm in his actions and omissions regarding the condition of the shared driveway.
Seigel v. Berkshire Life Ins. Co., 273 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a mortgagee’s duties when exercising a power of sale in a foreclosure and analyzes whether the foreclosure sale was conducted in good faith and with reasonable care to obtain a fair price. It does not involve a negligence or premises-liability context, a “shared driveway,” or a general duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable physical harm. The duty discussed is a contractual/foreclosure-related duty owed by a mortgagee to protect the mortgagor’s financial interests, not a tort duty regarding property conditions or a shared driveway.
Seigel v. Berkshire Life Ins. Co., 273 M.relevant_excerpt: “It is the duty of the mortgagee, where the mortgage leaves him a power of selection of methods of giving notice, and of making the sale, to act reasonably and to exercise a sound discretion. In such a case it is his duty to act as a reasonably prudent man would to obtain a fair price for property which has a well known value… A failure to change the terms of sale… or to adjourn the sale… coupled with a purchase by the mortgagee, would be evidence of a want of good faith and of neglect by the mortgagee…”

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, the Plaintiff suffered property damage, including a dented hood and cracked windshield, and incurred costs for vehicle repairs and rentals.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns a premises liability claim for negligent failure to provide security leading to a sexual assault; it does not involve property damage to a vehicle, dents, cracked windshields, or costs of vehicle repair or rental. The opinion addresses foreseeability, duty, and proximate cause in the context of personal injury from criminal assault, not property damage causation or the specific types of damages described in the proposition. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about vehicle property damage resulting from negligence.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff brought this action alleging that the defendant landlord negligently failed to provide adequate security in the building. … The basic question on the defendant’s appeal… is whether, in the circumstances, the evidence permitted a finding that the landlord had any duty to the plaintiff to guard against the criminal acts of the intruder. We conclude that the defendant had no such duty because the assault was not reasonably foreseeable.”

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence as defined under Massachusetts common law and statutory law.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The case expressly holds that, on these facts, there is no common-law duty and therefore no negligence liability for the defendant social host, and it also rejects the argument that the cited Massachusetts statutes independently create a tort duty. The opinion clarifies that violations of those alcohol-related statutes do not constitute negligence per se and that any liability must be grounded in common-law negligence, which is found lacking here. Thus, the decision undermines, rather than supports, the proposition that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law or statutory law.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: "Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence... It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2(a).proposition: Massachusetts General Laws (G.L. c. 93A, § 2(a) related by analogy to conduct amounting to negligence)

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The “proposition” here is simply the case citation itself, without any separate legal principle stated. The provided opinion text is in fact Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013), and it sets out the governing rule on a landowner’s duty to remedy open and obvious dangers. To the extent the citation is being used just to refer to this decision and its core holding—that a landowner may have a duty to remedy an open and obvious danger where he can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter it despite its obviousness—the opinion clearly supports that proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “Because we conclude that a landowner has a duty to remedy an open and obvious danger, where he has created and maintained that danger with the knowledge that lawful entrants would (and did) choose to encounter it despite the obvious risk of doing so, we now reverse.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition is simply the case citation itself, without any substantive legal principle attached. The provided opinion text is in fact Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), and thus the case obviously supports being cited for itself. The opinion clearly establishes its own holding abolishing the natural/unnatural snow-and-ice distinction and applying a general reasonable care standard.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.

Blye v. Boston Waterfront Corp., 130 Mas.raw_text: Blye v. Boston Waterfront Corp., 130 Mass. 85 (1881)
Blye v. Boston Waterfront Corp., 130 Mas.proposition: Blye v. Boston Waterfront Corp., 130 Mass. 85 (1881)
Blye v. Boston Waterfront Corp., 130 Mas.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is just the case citation repeated, without stating any legal principle, so there is nothing substantive to compare the opinion against. Because no concrete rule or proposition is specified, I cannot say the opinion supports it in any meaningful way.
Blye v. Boston Waterfront Corp., 130 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "Nor can it be said, as matter of law, that the petitioner had constructive notice of the existence of the notes and mortgage, because the mortgage was duly recorded in the registry of deeds in the county of Hampshire. It is provided in the Gen. Sts. c. 89, § 3, that no sale or conveyance of land shall be valid against any person other than the grantor, his heirs and devisees, and persons having actual notice thereof, unless made by a deed duly recorded. But this provision relates to the transfer and conveyance of real estate, and is intended to prevent fraudulent or clandestine conveyances of land..."

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.proposition: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.support_reasoning: The "proposition" as stated is just a repetition of the case citation and does not articulate any specific legal principle to be tested against the opinion. The opinion itself discusses foreseeability, duty, and premises liability in the context of a car crashing into a restaurant, and holds that such an event was not reasonably foreseeable on the facts presented. Without a concrete legal proposition (e.g., about foreseeability or duty) to compare, it is not possible to say the case supports the bare citation-as-proposition.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.relevant_excerpt: The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.

Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav.,.raw_text: Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav., 313 Mass. 315 (1943)
Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav.,.proposition: Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav., 313 Mass. 315 (1943)
Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav.,.support_reasoning: Because the proposition is simply the case citation itself with no additional legal rule stated, the opinion necessarily supports it: the quoted text is in fact from Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav., 313 Mass. 315 (1943). There is no mismatch between the cited case and the provided opinion text.
Beckett v. Warren Institution for Sav.,.relevant_excerpt: A trade name can have no existence in gross, unconnected with some business in which it is used. Jackman v. Calvert-Distillers Corp. of Massachusetts, 306 Mass. 423, 426. When the defendant had gone out of the business in question, and had abandoned the name, he ceased to have any further right in it. It was then open to the plaintiff to adopt it as his own. Cohen v. Nagle, 190 Mass. 4, 11. The right to it could not thereafter be resumed by the defendant.
